author: jtraglia
content: Yeah this is interesting problem. I'm pretty sure it's the runners. I just re-tested this using vmcli on my M1 macbook. It's just a little slower on Linux but that's somewhat expected. The benchmarks:

author: rjected
content: still important to do a real test imo. vm might be good at translation to something we know is already good at kzg (m1)

author: jtraglia
content: Yeah that's fair. I've also tested on a Rock5 model B. I'm not at home right now and can't re-run benchmarks, but here's some benchmarks for the new DAS functions. Should give an idea of how much slower it is. It's ~6x slower than my macbook. But this is also expected as it's a pretty weak CPU.

author: jtraglia
content: It's about 3x less powerful on geekbench & it doesn't support ARM64_CRYPTO instructions.

author: jtraglia
content: Do we know which CPU the github runners use?

author: rjected
content: hmmm, not sure, possible the runners are both weak and don't support the right instructions, trying to find more info online

author: rjected
content:
https://browser.geekbench.com/v5/cpu/compare/22236423?baseline=21070727
github mentions they use some ampere altra family chip
https://github.blog/changelog/2023-10-30-accelerate-your-ci-cd-with-arm-based-hosted-runners-in-github-actions/

author: rjected
content: so the M1 is probably just way better

author: jtraglia
content: So I hadn't actually looked at the benchmarks in that PR (https://github.com/ethereum/c-kzg-4844/actions/runs/7769552403/job/21191010428 then click benchmark) until just now. Wow it's extremely slow. It takes 76ms to verify a kzg proof. This takes about 1ms on other arm64/x86 CPUs. It's hard to believe the Altra core is that slow here. The geekbench link you shared claims that single core performance is 2x worse than the M1, which doesn't really track what we see.

author: parithosh
content: We have a rocks5b that we could use for testing and otherwise I think the hetzner cloud arm machines are not a bad benchmark target.
